item.title: Five Tips To Get The Most Out Of Video Interviews
item.dc:creator: Prime Pharmacy
item.description: The post Five Tips To Get The Most Out Of Video Interviews appeared first on Prime Pharmacy.
item.content:encoded:
Video interviews are now becoming commonplace to conduct the interview process with video platforms such as ZOOM, Skype, Google Duo and Whatsapp as some examples being used.

Now with COVID-19 creating restrictions of movement, even within pharmacies, companies are reviewing how they can recruit pharmacy staff and onboard to continue finding the best pharmacy talent.Â 

We wanted to share our 5 top tips for pharmacy candidates who have a video interview coming up.

1. Reliable Internet Connection

Firstly, make sure you have downloaded the relevant video interview software that the pharmacy company has requested to use for the video interview.

Critically your internet connection should be strong, preferably private domestic broadband, and your device suitably powered and charged.

If your internet isn’t great, consider using your mobile device on 4G.

2. Ideal surroundings

Ensure you are located in a quiet area with no background interference. This is important for technical performance, but also for the concentration of both parties. Show care for yourself and the employer by arranging an optimum space.

Itâs likely that youâll choose a room at home where you can sit stationary and privately â possibly a bedroom or office. Check what the camera has in view. You might then discover you need to clear the space behind you temporarily or adjust things like lighting and your chair position. . No one is expecting or suggesting studio-perfect conditions, but simple things make a big difference.

3. Clothing

The appropriate dress code for a video interview is a popular concern. Itâs easy to become slightly self-conscious about dressing so formally for what is essentially a video chat. However the answer is very simple â you should approach it in exactly the same way as you would a normal interview.

4. Body language

Just like with a normal interview, your general body language should show confidence. The basic requirement here is that your poise and posture is of someone ready and capable. Donât let the less formal surroundings or perception of a video interview impair your physical demeanour.

You will want your body language to operate within the confines of the camera. Technically you should be seated still and positioned so as not to inadvertently move out of shot. So while talking with your hands and expressing yourself naturally is encouraged, gesticulating so wildly that your face disappears is less effective.

5. General etiquette

  1. Start by checking that both you and the interviewer can see and hear each other clearly.
  2. Be cordial, listen out for names and refer to them and maintain eye contact where feasible.
  3. Heighten the expressions in your voice and speak loudly and clearly.
  4. Punctuate your answers to avoid confusion
  5. Allow ample response times for any possible lag.
The Takeaway

The main thing to remember when approaching a video interview is not to treat it too differently to the traditional kind!

item.title: 4 top reasons to become a Community Pharmacist
item.dc:creator: Prime Pharmacy
item.description: The post 4 top reasons to become a Community Pharmacist appeared first on Prime Pharmacy.
item.content:encoded:
As a GPhC qualified pharmacist you will consider all your job opportunities when choosing your next career move. There are many different pharmacy opportunities to consider such as a relief pharmacist, clinical pharmacist, community pharmacist to name some.

Community pharmacists are the most visible type of pharmacist in the UK, and like GPâs, are part of the NHS family. Community pharmacist can also be known as Chemists and can be found on the high streets, next to medical practices, in hospitals or in large supermarkets.

 

As a community pharmacist your job would be all about helping patients and customers, assessing their conditions and making decisions about which medicines they should take. Youâll be involved in depending medicines and offering your patients advice and practical help on keeping healthy. Itâs a very responsible job and you will be highly respected member of the community.

 

Here are 4 proâs and conâs to consider before you take that Community Pharmacist role.

1. The hours are usually regular

 

A common reason amongst community pharmacists is the hours are sociable and are set each week.Â  This enables the Pharmacist to have a home/ work life balance.

2. You have direct interaction with your customers

As you are working within the community you will be able to build a rapport with you customers, giving the customer a better experience but also gives the pharmacist a much more holistic idea of the customers lifestyle enable him to provide better and more targeted counselling.

3. You have a varied workload

You will have to handle a variety of responsibilities. This may include things like vaccinations, medication therapy management, comprehensive medication reviews, handling inventory, supervising staff, handling budgets as well as dispensing prescriptions and over the counter medication, conducting health checks such as screening for diabetes or blood pressure checks.

4. There is a real shortage of community pharmacists in the UK

In 2019, there were on average 2 pharmacies in the UK per 10,000 people and only 11,539* qualified community pharmacists. Therefore, 1 community pharmacist will be servicing nearly 6,000 people in their community.Â  There were over one billion prescriptions dispensed in 2019, which on average works out at 237 prescriptions dispensed each day per pharmacist. Which means there is a real shortage of pharmacists for the community. These numbers are only increasing so the demand for community pharmacists will only increase.

Although there was a report in 2013 stipulating that there were to be a surplus of pharmacists by 2013, that situation has now reversed and there is mounting concern among NHS leaders from across England that there are not enough pharmacists to meet demand.

There is a higher shortage of community pharmacists in rural and remote areas of the UK, which is only going to be made worse as pharmacy student numbers dwindle.

The Takeaway

Being a community pharmacist does come with its own drawbacks but what job doesnât! You will have some tired feet and some bad customer experience stories to tell, but the job can also be extremely rewarding and satisfying.

As the demand for pharmacists and more specifically community pharmacists continue to outweigh supply, we are more likely to see an upward trajectory in average salaries across the board for the community pharmacist, as you become a precious resource to the NHS.

As a community pharmacist you will take on additional business responsibilities beyond your pharmacy qualification, this will give you with the knowledge and the skills to possibly even set up your own Chemist in the future.
